title: ‘There’s always this feeling of, “Do I belong here?”’
text:
As the daughter of two Spanish-speaking immigrants, Jessica Rodriguez said she was well-acquainted with feelings of not belonging, or of unacceptance. | Getty Images Women Rule podcast ‘There’s always this feeling of, “Do I belong here?”’ Jessica Rodriguez, president of entertainment and CMO of Univision, on the challenges of being both American and Hispanic in 2019.

Subscribe to Women Rule on Apple Podcasts here. | Subscribe via Spotify here.

When a white 21-year-old Texas man opened fire in an El Paso Wal-Mart earlier this month, murdering 22 people and jolting a nation seemingly numb to mass shootings, his goal was, in part, to terrorize American Hispanics. In a racist online manifesto posted shortly before he opened fire, he cited the “Hispanic invasion of Texas” as the motivation for the massacre.

Story Continued Below

He hoped that his act of terror would make Hispanics cower in fear. But Jessica Rodriguez, president of entertainment and CMO of Univision, says that it has only strengthened the bonds within the community—and underscored the importance of service-oriented journalism like Univision’s.

“It absolutely affects us all deeply. Personally, as a Latina as well, absolutely. It affects each and every one of us,” Rodriguez said during an interview for POLITICO’s Women Rule podcast . “But whether it’s the children on the border, whether it’s what’s happening with our Dreamers, whether it’s how do we prepare our young, growing Latino population to register to vote, how do we prepare and inform them in the elections, how do we get them ready for the Census—we’re going to be there. … And we’re going to be there not shying away from those topics, because that’s what our community deserves.”

As the daughter of two Spanish-speaking immigrants, Rodriguez said she was well-acquainted with feelings of not belonging, or of unacceptance.

“As a Latino, you straddle a little bit this idea of like, ‘Well, what am I, right?’ Am I American? I don’t feel I’m as American as I should be to my American friends,” Rodriguez said. “But then from my Latino friends, I’m not as Latino as they expect.”

She spoke Spanish at home, but English in the outside world—as her parents wanted. “I just remember very vividly them sitting down with me and saying that it’s like, ‘Look, you live here in the United States. You’re in New York City. You’re going to make a lot of friends who speak English. You’re going to want to be American—whatever that means—Jessica. But I want it to be very clear about something: You are Latino, and in this house … you’re going to speak Spanish and you’re going to learn about your culture.”

She watched the typical late-80s and early-90s teen fare, like “Beverly Hills, 90210,” but also telenovelas and Spanish-language news on Univision. People like her seemed all but invisible in the English-language media.

“I’m looking at the Nielsen ratings and I’m seeing what are the top shows in America and again, I’m seeing all these shows that I just mentioned to you, and there is not one Spanish-language show,” said Rodriguez. “I’m like, ‘Well, every Latino in this country knows you grow up watching “Sábado Gigante,” or … one of the great telenovelas.’ … And it was just like a very frustrating thing to not see that my community and myself was being represented in media.”

“There’s always this feeling of, ‘Do I belong here?’” Rodriguez said. “As a Latino, and I think even more now in this era that we’re living in, sometimes there’s feelings of like, ‘I don’t belong here. I’m not wanted here, right?’”

All of which has helped inform Rodriguez’s outlook for Univision in 2019 America. She’s bolstered the diversity on the network, bringing more women into positions of power and representing the array of Americans included in blanket terms like “Hispanic” or “Latino.”

“One of our morning news anchors became a citizen and what was really … lovely and inspiring was the fact that we actually covered her ceremony,” said Rodriguez. “She flew in family from Honduras, and it was really beautiful to be able to showcase that, to bring that in a very real way to our audiences. Because I think with everything, if you see things in the abstract, you may not connect to it. But there’s so much inspiration in terms of just the everyday stories that we see from our own talent, right? That I think again, allows our audience to see themselves reflected in our programming and our content.”

“One of the things that is really important when we speak about the ‘Hispanic population’ is that we have to respect and honor and understand that everybody comes to their duality as a Latino—you’re 100 percent American and 100 percent Latino—in very different ways,” said Rodriguez.

In that way, Rodriguez’s Univision is sharing a message to Hispanics and Latinos about life in America — one that needs to be heard, especially now: You belong.

To hear more from Jessica Rodriguez, listen to the full podcast here. Women Rule takes listeners backstage with female bosses for real talk on how they made it and what advice they have for women looking to lead.

CORRECTION: An earlier version of this story misidentified Jessica Rodriguez's roles at Univision.
